epidemiology.formula: Epidemiology studies disease distribution, determinants, and control strategies in populations
epidemiology.correct: Epidemiologists track disease patterns to identify causes and implement effective control measures

wrong.error: Limiting scope based on word similarity
wrong.fix: Epidemiology studies all disease patterns, not just epidemics
wrong.action: Epidemiology = study of disease distribution and control in populations

wrong.answer: Epidemiology focuses on treating individual patients
wrong.fix: Epidemiology focuses on populations; clinical medicine treats individuals
wrong.action: Epidemiology = population level; Medicine = individual level

wrong.fix: Epidemiology includes developing and evaluating control strategies
wrong.action: Epidemiology: study patterns + implement control measures

persistent.action: Epidemiology: distribution (where/who), determinants (why), control (how to stop)

pathogen_identification.formula: Pathogens are identified using screening tests (high-risk detection) and diagnostic tests (definitive identification)
pathogen_identification.correct: Screening identifies at-risk individuals; diagnostic tests confirm presence or absence of disease

wrong.fix: Screening identifies high-risk individuals; diagnosis confirms disease presence
wrong.action: Screening = identifies risk; Diagnostic = confirms disease

wrong.answer: Diagnostic tests are used for asymptomatic populations
wrong.fix: Screening is for asymptomatic populations; diagnostics are for symptomatic or high-risk individuals
wrong.action: Screening = asymptomatic; Diagnostic = symptomatic/high-risk

wrong.answer: All tests have the same accuracy
wrong.fix: Tests vary in sensitivity and specificity; screening prioritises sensitivity, diagnosis prioritises specificity
wrong.action: Screening = high sensitivity; Diagnosis = high specificity

persistent.gap: Confusion between screening and diagnostic tests
persistent.action: Screening: asymptomatic, identifies risk; Diagnostic: confirms presence/absence

pcr_testing.formula: PCR amplifies pathogen-specific genetic sequences to detect infection with high sensitivity
pcr_testing.correct: Fluorescent primers target viral sequences; amplification indicates active infection in the sample

wrong.fix: PCR detects genetic material (DNA/RNA); antibody tests detect immune responses
wrong.action: PCR = genetic material; ELISA/serology = antibodies

wrong.answer: PCR cannot distinguish current from past infection
wrong.fix: PCR detects active infection (genetic material present); antibody tests may indicate past infection
wrong.action: PCR = current infection; Antibodies = current or past

wrong.fix: PCR works by amplifying (copying) target sequences millions of times for detection
wrong.action: PCR = Polymerase Chain Reaction = amplification is essential

persistent.action: PCR: target sequence + primers + polymerase → amplification → detection

elisa_testing.formula: ELISA uses antibodies to capture and detect specific antigens or antibodies in samples
elisa_testing.correct: Capture antibodies trap targets; detection antibodies linked to enzymes provide colour change for identification

wrong.fix: ELISA detects proteins (antigens/antibodies); PCR amplifies nucleic acids
wrong.action: ELISA = protein detection; PCR = genetic amplification

wrong.fix: ELISA = Enzyme-Linked Immunosorbent Assay; enzymes are essential for detection
wrong.action: Enzymes linked to detection antibodies produce colour change

wrong.answer: ELISA is always a diagnostic test
wrong.fix: ELISA is typically used for screening; low antigen levels may limit diagnostic accuracy
wrong.action: ELISA often screening; confirmatory tests may be needed for diagnosis

persistent.gap: Confusion about ELISA mechanism and application
persistent.action: ELISA: capture antibody + target + detection antibody-enzyme → colour = positive

transmission_modes.formula: Pathogens spread through direct contact, droplets, airborne particles, vehicles, or vectors
transmission_modes.correct: Direct transmission requires contact; indirect transmission uses intermediate vehicles or vectors

wrong.answer: All pathogens spread the same way
wrong.fix: Different pathogens have different transmission modes that affect control strategies
wrong.action: Know the transmission mode → design appropriate control measures

wrong.answer: Droplet and airborne transmission are identical
wrong.fix: Droplets are larger and fall quickly; airborne particles are smaller and travel further
wrong.action: Droplets = close contact; Airborne = can spread widely

wrong.fix: Vectors are living organisms (mosquitoes, ticks); fomites are non-living objects
wrong.action: Vectors = living carriers; Fomites = contaminated objects

persistent.action: Direct: contact, droplet; Indirect: airborne, vehicle (fomite), vector (living)

zoonotic_diseases.formula: Zoonotic diseases transfer from animal hosts to humans, with animals serving as pathogen reservoirs
zoonotic_diseases.correct: Animal reservoirs allow pathogens to persist even if eliminated from human populations

wrong.answer: Zoonotic diseases only come from domestic animals
wrong.fix: Zoonotic diseases come from wild and domestic animals; wildlife is a major source
wrong.action: Zoonoses from wildlife (bats, rodents) and domestic animals (dogs, livestock)

wrong.answer: Eliminating zoonotic disease in humans eliminates it completely
wrong.fix: Animal reservoirs can re-introduce the disease even after elimination in humans
wrong.action: Animal reservoirs = persistence + re-emergence potential

wrong.fix: Many pandemics (influenza, COVID-19) originated from zoonotic spillover
wrong.action: Zoonotic spillover = major pandemic source

persistent.gap: Incomplete understanding of zoonotic disease dynamics
persistent.action: Zoonotic: animal reservoir → spillover to humans → potential human-to-human spread

vector_borne.formula: Vector-borne diseases use living organisms to transmit pathogens between hosts
vector_borne.correct: Biological vectors harbour pathogens during their life cycle; mechanical vectors transport pathogens externally

wrong.fix: Vectors include insects (mosquitoes, flies), arachnids (ticks, mites), and other animals
wrong.action: Vectors: mosquitoes, ticks, fleas, sandflies, snails, etc.

wrong.answer: Biological and mechanical vectors function identically
wrong.fix: Biological vectors are infected (pathogen replicates); mechanical vectors just transport externally
wrong.action: Biological = infected; Mechanical = contaminated surface

wrong.fix: Vector control includes insecticides, habitat modification, and biological control
wrong.action: Vector control: chemicals, environment modification, sterile release

persistent.action: Biological vector: pathogen develops inside; Mechanical vector: external carriage

control_strategies.formula: Disease control uses scientific strategies (vaccination, treatment) supported by social strategies (policies, education)
control_strategies.correct: Scientific strategies directly target transmission; social strategies ensure implementation and compliance

wrong.fix: Social strategies (education, policy) are essential for implementing medical interventions
wrong.action: Both scientific AND social strategies needed for effective control

wrong.answer: Control strategies are the same for all diseases
wrong.fix: Control strategies must match the pathogen's transmission mode and characteristics
wrong.action: Know the pathogen → design specific control measures

wrong.fix: Social strategies are informed by behavioural science and public health evidence
wrong.action: Social strategies: evidence-based education, policy, and communication

persistent.action: Scientific (what to do) + Social (how to ensure it happens) = effective control
